Is the crash a SIGSEGV?

We've seen those on our spanking-new dual-opteron systems
intermittently. Our current theory is that it's a JVM GC
issue; at least one crash output log showed a "GCTaskThread"
as the culprit.

Using the "-XX:+UseSerialGC" to force the use of the classic
garbage collector (which is still the default on uniprocessor
and <2GB RAM machines) has, so far, cleared our crashes up.

One other gotcha I *think* I've seen with the Sun 1.5.0_03
64bit JVM: using the nifty new 'jmap' and 'jstack' utilities
seems to be correlated with JVM lockups, where threads
wind up waiting for wake signals that never arrive. In some
such lockups, even a 'kill -9' won't exit the JVM -- only
connecting to the process with 'gdb' and issuing its internal
'kill' command works.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA

Matt Ittigson wrote:
> I'm having a problem (this time I'm sure its actually with Heritrix)
> with hard crashes.  I have the hs_err_pidXXX.logs and the
> heritrix_out.log, but neither points me clearly toward the problem. 
> I'm running Heritrix-200505310807 (though I've had crashes with
> previous versions, including 1.4, as well) on a dual Opteron, with 2G
> of ram, running Linux 2.6.9, glibc 2.3.4, JVM 1.5.0_03.
> 
> Is there some logging I could turn on (or perhaps somewhere I could
> look) which could point me toward the right direction?  I'm guessing
> it has to do with a certain URL getting hit, which causes the crash,
> so if I could narrow down what exactly Heritrix is up to right before,
> maybe I could figure out how to skip the particular URL's.
> 
> A little more information:  In the past, the crashes have mostly been
> consistent.  My previous usage model was to break large seed files
> into smaller chunks, and Heritrix would usually crash consistently on
> the chunks with problems.  Sometimes, re-running a seed chunk which
> would cause a crash could run to competion without crashing (becase I
> retire host-based queues at 200 URL's, this could be due to the bad
> URL being occasionally skipped for being out of scope), but most of
> the time the crash would be consistent.  I'm now continually loading
> seeds via cmdline-jmx.  I've changed my program to output exactly at
> what point the crash happens (when the connection is refused), but
> that won't really make clear exactly which URL's are being crawled at
> the time.
> 
> Are there known bugs that would cause hard crashes I could look into? 
> Would posting the log files to this list help debug the problem?  Is
> there logging I could turn on to show exactly what was being crawled
> at the time of the crash?  Any other ideas of approaches to take
> toward solving the problem?
> 
> Thanks.
>
